__data__.text:
POTENCIA: CLASS 4
THURSDAY SEPTEMBER 10, 2020
8 – 9 PM
CHECKING IN 
HOW ARE YOU FEELING?
R: TODAY I FEEL ________

WHAT DID YOU DO TODAY?
R: TODAY I ________
Emotions
REVIEW FROM LAST CLASS
WEATHER/TEMPERATURE, MONTHS, SEASONS:
WHAT MONTH IS IT?
WHAT MONTH COMES NEXT?
WHAT IS YOUR FAVORITE SEASON?
HOW WAS THE WEATHER TODAY?
THE 5 W’S + HOW: PLEASE TRANSLATE FROM ENGLISH TO PORTUGUESE
HOW
WHAT
WHERE
WHEN
WHY
WHO
PLAN FOR TODAY
REVIEW WHAT IS A 
NOUN
LEARN THE BASIC RULES OF 
FORMING A PLURAL NOUN
LEARN ABOUT 
ARTICLES
 IN ENGLISH
PRACTICE 
IDENTIFYING A NOUN 
IN A SENTENCE
PRACTICE IDENTIFYING THE 
CORRECT FORM OF A NOUN
NOUNS
WHAT IS A NOUN?
Noun: person, place, or thing/object
NOUNS CAN BE SINGULAR OR PLURAL
Eyes
Snow
Hand
Mouth
Sun
See
Snowing
Touch
Eat
Sunny
Which group is made up of nouns?
Group A
Group B
Person
Mother/Father 
Daughter/Son
Girl/Boy 
Woman/Man
Doctor
Teacher
Place
Beach
School
House
Bakery
Medford
Thing/object
Computer
Shoe
Ear
Pencil
Book
QUICK ACTIVITY
IDENTIFY THE NOUN AND SAY IF IT IS A PERSON, PLACE, OR OBJECT.
TRANSLATE TO PORTUGUESE!

I have a son.
I am from brazil.
My eyes are tired.
The girl is here.
The pencil is red.
The tree is tall.


TURNING A SINGULAR NOUN INTO A PLURAL NOUN: BASIC RULES
FOR MOST SINGULAR NOUNS, 
ADD ‘S’ AT THE END
Window 🡪 
windows
Ear 🡪 
ears
Eye 🡪 
eyes
Hand 🡪 
hands
FOR SINGULAR NOUNS THAT 
END IN CH, X, Z, S, SH, OR SS
, 
ADD ‘ES’ AT THE END
Wat
ch
 🡪 
watches
Bu
s
 🡪 
buses
Bo
x
 🡪 
boxes
Mo
ss
 🡪 
mosses






TURNING A SINGULAR NOUN INTO A PLURAL NOUN: BASIC RULES
FOR SINGULAR NOUNS THAT 
END IN F OR FE
, 
CHANGE F TO ‘V’ AND ADD ‘ES’
Calf 🡪 
calves
Wolf 🡪 
wolves
Leaf 🡪 
leaves
Life 🡪 
lives



OTHER RULES
SOME NOUNS HAVE DIFFERENT PLURAL FORMS


NOUNS ENDING IN VOWELS LIKE Y OR O DO NOT HAVE DEFINITE RULES 
(SPELLING)
Baby 🡪 
babies
Potato 🡪 
potatoes
Toy 🡪 
toys
A FEW NOUNS HAVE THE SAME SINGULAR AND PLURAL FORMS
Sheep
Fish
Series


Tooth 🡪 
teeth
Goose 🡪 
geese
Mouse 🡪 
mice

Nouns that end in y
: many times, 
remove y
 and 
replace with “ies”
Nouns that end in o
: many times, 
remove o
 and 
replace with “oes”
Child 🡪 
children	
Woman 🡪 
women
Man 🡪 
men
SUMMARY OF RULES
ARTICLES
WHAT IS AN ARTICLE?
*Articles tell us if something is specific (definite) or non-specific (non-definite)
They can also help us see if something is singular or plural
WHAT ARTICLES DO WE SEE IN ENGLISH?
The
Some
A
An

__data__.text:
Tooth 🡪 
teeth
Goose 🡪 
geese
Mouse 🡪 
mice

Nouns that end in y
: many times, 
remove y
 and 
replace with “ies”
Nouns that end in o
: many times, 
remove o
 and 
replace with “oes”
Child 🡪 
children	
Woman 🡪 
women
Man 🡪 
men
SUMMARY OF RULES
ARTICLES
WHAT IS AN ARTICLE?
*Articles tell us if something is specific (definite) or non-specific (non-definite)
They can also help us see if something is singular or plural
WHAT ARTICLES DO WE SEE IN ENGLISH?
The
Some
A
An 


Definite; something particular
Indefinite; a general idea/thing
SUMMARY
*There are some exceptions with A/An:
My mother is 
an
 honest woman.
My mother is 
a 
honest woman.

She is 
a
 United States senator.
She is 
an
 United States senator.
ACTIVITY 1: ARTICLES
IDENTIFY THE ARTICLE AND THE NOUN
IS THE ARTICLE DEFINITE OR INDEFINITE? 
IS THE NOUN SINGULAR, PLURAL, OR UNCOUNTABLE?

Can you get me the pencil?
Please give me a cup of tea.
Are you going to the party?
Can you get me some water?
Some people like cold weather.
ACTIVITY 2: ABOUT BRAZIL
IDENTIFY THE CORRECT ARTICLE
Brazil is _____ largest country in South America and _____ fifth largest nation in the world. It forms _____ enormous triangle on the eastern side of the continent with a 4,500-mile (7,400-kilometer) coastline along _____ Atlantic ocean. 
Northern brazil is dominated by _____ Amazon River and the jungles that surround it
Brazilians are soccer crazy, and their country has produced _____ of the best players.
ACTIVITY 3: ARTICLES & NOUNS
IDENTIFY THE ARTICLES (IF THERE ARE ANY)
CHOOSE THE CORRECT FORM OF THE NOUN IN EACH SENTENCE:

I have three (child, children).
There are five (man, men) and one (woman, women).
I put two big (potato, potatoes) in the lunch box.
A few men wear (watch, watches).
I put a (note, notes) on the desk.
I saw a (mouse, mice) running by.
There are few (bus, buses) on the road today.
ACTIVITY 4: SINGULAR TO PLURAL NOUNS
IDENTIFY THE NOUN. THEN, CHANGE IT FROM SINGULAR TO PLURAL.
TRANSLATE THE SENTENCE!

My sweater is black.
My eye is brown.
My foot hurts.
The door is open.
Can 
I
 have some coffee?
Please turn off the light.



🡪 My 
sweaters are 
black. 
LESSON SUMMARY
TODAY WE:
IDENTIFIED NOUNS IN A SENTENCE
PRACTICED CHANGING SINGULAR NOUNS TO PLURAL NOUNS
LEARNED ABOUT ARTICLES IN ENGLISH
CONTACT INFORMATION
BEVERLY.REYES@TUFTS.EDU
WHATSAPP: 203-550-4184
CLASSES ON THURSDAYS 8PM

__data__.text:
Class 2
The Verb: “To be”

Before we begin… (antes de começarmos…)
❖
Email? 
❖
Eu estarei falando em inglês para você se acostumar; mas, 
tudo será escrito em inglês e em português. Consulte o 
inglês e também o português para ajudá-lo a praticar.
❖
Lembre-se de me perguntar se você tiver alguma dúvida ou 
se eu for muito rápido. Você pode falar em português, mas 
tente usar o máximo de inglês que você souber.

Warm Up! (Fale antes de aula)
How are you today?
Como você está hoje?
How was work?
Como foi o trabalho?

The Verb : “To be”
o verbo: “ser”

Pronouns (Pronomes)
❖
É o verbo inglês : “ser”
❖
Some examples we have used in greetings:
Alguns exemplos que usamos em saudações:
★
How are you?
★
I am good.
★
What is your name?
★
My name is Camila.

Pronouns (Pronomes)- Present (tempo presente)
I am                    We are
You are               You (all) are
He is/She is        They are
Irregular (verbo irregular)

When do we use “to be”? (Quando usamos “to be”?)
❖We use it to describe something or someone.
Nós o usamos para descrever algo ou alguém.

When do we use “to be”? (Quando usamos “to be”?)
❖
Names (Nomes)
➢
I am Camila.
➢
Eu sou Camila.
❖
Age (Idade)
➢
I am 19 years old. I am 
young.
➢
Eu tenho 19 anos de idade. 
Sou jovem.
❖
Feelings (Sentimentos)
➢
I am happy. I am sad.
➢
Eu estou feliz. Eu estou 
triste.
❖
Nationality/Location 
(Nacionalidade/localização)
➢
I am from Argentina. I am 
in Boston.
➢
Eu sou da Argentina. Eu 
estou em Boston.
❖
Occupation (Ocupação)
➢
I am a student.
➢
Eu sou um estudante.
❖
Time (Hora)
➢
It is 1 o’clock.
➢
É 1 hora.

When do we use “to be”? (Quando usamos “to be”?)
❖
“to be” can also be used as a way to talk about what someone is 
doing.
“to be” também pode ser usado como uma forma de falar sobre o 
que alguém está fazendo.
❖
Examples (exemplos):
➢
I am writing. 
➢
Eu estou escrevendo.
➢
She is speaking.
➢
Ela está felando.

Video (vídeo)

Speaking Activity (Actividade de Falar)
❖We are going to familiarize ourselves with diﬀerent 
conjugations of “to be.”
Vamos nos familiarizar com as diferentes conjugações 
de ”ser.”
❖On our next slides, please read the phrases and ﬁll-in the 
blanks with the correct form of “to be.”
Nos próximos slides, por favor leia as frases e preencha 
o espaço em branco com a forma correta de “ser.”

Practice (praticar)
I ___ Susan. 
She ____ 20 years old.
You ____ happy.
She ____ French.
I __ a teacher.
You ____ are writing.

Practice (praticar)
They ____ Sam, Tom, and Peter.
He ___ young.
You all ___ ﬁne.
We ___ from Australia.
He ___ a student.
They ___ are walking.

Referring to Objects (referindo-se a objetos)
❖
Use the phrase: “it is…” using the same conjunction as  “she/he 
is”; “they are…” if plural.
Use a frase: “it is…” conugando-a da mesma forma que “she/he 
is”; “they are…” se for plural
❖
Examples:
➢
It is a book.
➢
They are toys.
➢
It is a basketball.

She ____ 20 years old.
You ____ happy.
She ____ French.
I __ a teacher.
You ____ are writing.

Practice (praticar)
They ____ Sam, Tom, and Peter.
He ___ young.
You all ___ ﬁne.
We ___ from Australia.
He ___ a student.
They ___ are walking.

Referring to Objects (referindo-se a objetos)
❖
Use the phrase: “it is…” using the same conjunction as  “she/he 
is”; “they are…” if plural.
Use a frase: “it is…” conugando-a da mesma forma que “she/he 
is”; “they are…” se for plural
❖
Examples:
➢
It is a book.
➢
They are toys.
➢
It is a basketball.

You (all) are (vocês sâo)
❖
This is used to talk about a group of people (men or women or both)
Isso é usado para falar sobre um grupo de pessoas (homens ou 
mulheres ou ambos)
❖
In the northeast of the United States,  we use “you guys” more 
commonly and informally.
No nordeste dos Estados Unidos, usamos “you guys” mais 
comumente e informalmente.
❖
Examples:
➢
You guys are nice.
➢
You guys are from Brazil.

Contractions (contrações)
❖
Usually, when speaking and sometimes in books, “I am” becomes 
“I’m”
Normalement, ao falar e às vezes em livros, “I am” torna-se “I’m”
❖
Example:
➢
What is your name? I’m Camila.
❖
Other conjugations (outras contrações)
➢
You are= you’re
➢
They are= they’re
➢
We are= we’re
➢
He is= he’s
➢
She is=she’s

Homework
Dever de casa
Look at the following paragraph 
and ﬁll in the blank using the 
correct form of “to be.”
Leia o parágrafo a seguir e 
preencha o espaço em branco 
usando a forma correta de "ser".

Homework (dever de casa)
Hello, my name __ Sam. I __ 20 years old. I __ tall and I have brown hair with 
green eyes. There __ five people in my family. I have one brothers and one sister.  
My sister __ short and her eyes __ brown. Her hair __ not red. It __ blonde. My 
younger brother __ more similar to me. His hair __ red and he __ very tall. He __ 
only 2 years old. My parents both have brown hair and green eyes. We __ a happy 
family. We __ not lazy.  We ___ active and healthy. I love playing soccer in my free 
time and so do my brother and sister.  We want to be professional soccer players in 
the future.

Extra
❖
Practice with friends who know 
English.
❖
Watch a show or movie in English 
with Portuguese subtitles.
❖
Use Google Translate to look up new 
vocab words when you do not know 
something.
❖
Pratique com amigos que sabem 
inglês.
❖
Assista a um programa ou ﬁlme em 
inglês com legendas em português.
❖
Use o Google Translate para 
procurar novas palavras quando 
você não souber algo.

Thank you!
See you next time!
Obrigado! 
Vejo você na próxima 
vez!

__data__.text:
Thursday, October 1, 2020
8 – 9pm
Class 7
Checking in
How are you feeling today?
Today I feel _________
What did you do today?
Today I _________
Stressed = 
estresada
It is the month of October!
…
What things do you associate with this month?
Fall, Autumn
Foliage, (leaf) leaves falling
Winter is near 
Cool weather
When I think of October, I think of…
Colorful
The 5 W’s + How 
 Asking questions
Who  
quem
What 
 que?
When 
 
cuando
Where 
 
onde
Why 
 por que
How 
 
como
What is a noun?
Count nouns (next slide)
Review from past classes
Count nouns VS non-count nouns
Count nouns
Can be separated into individual units and counted
Eye, hand, ear, finger, leg
Singular vs plural form
Plural form 
 add s at the end
Eyes, hands, ears, fingers, legs
Non-count (uncountable) nouns
Exist as masses or abstract quantities that can’t be counted
Water, wood, air, rice, sunshine, rain, soccer
Generally can’t be pluralized
Activity: categorize the nouns
Count nouns
Non-count nouns
Sugar
Wine
Box
Pen
Computer
Wood
House
Wolf
Sunshine
Wind
Plan for today
Today we will learn about possessive nouns
What are they?
Differences between Portuguese and English
Today’s plan
Possessive nouns
Possessive nouns
Possessive nouns: used to indicate ownership
Show that a person, place, or thing owns something
Usually are formed by adding an apostrophe (‘s) and s
Beverly’s pen
Felipe’s eyes
Grandma’s house
Este 
é
 
o 
livro
 de Beverly.
Direct translation: This is 
the book of Beverly.
Correct translation: This is 
Beverly’s book.
Translating from Portuguese to English
Os
 
olhos
 do Felipe 
são
 
azuis
.
Direct translation: 
The eyes of Felipe 
are blue.
Correct translation: 
Felipe’s eyes 
are blue.
Translating from Portuguese to English
Esta
 
é
 
a casa de 
minha
 
avó
.
Direct translation: This is 
the house of 
my 
grandmother.
Correct translation: This is my 
grandmother’s house.
Translating from Portuguese to English
Summary: rules for possessive nouns
(rule 1 & 2)
Activity: make the singular nouns possessive
Examples:
Felipe  
Felipe’s
Cat  
cat’s
Brazil  
Brazil’s
Computer  
computer’s
Practice:
Phone 
 ___________
Sun  ___________
House  ___________
Dog  ___________
Tree  ___________
Grandmother 
 ___________
Country  ___________
Phone’s
Sun’s
Examples:
Hands 
 hands’
Trees  trees’
People  people’s
Feet  feet’s
Practice:
Monsters 
 __________
Teeth  __________
Eyes 
 __________
Spiders 
 __________
Pumpkins 
 __________
Parents 
 __________
Activity: make the plural nouns possessive
Monsters’
Teeth’s
Eyes’
Some rules about possessive nouns
Singular possessive nouns: formed by adding ‘s at the end
Grandmother’s house
Plural possessive nouns [and plural possessive nouns that end in S]: when a noun is plural, just add the apostrophe (‘)
Casa dos meus 
pais
 
 My parents’ house
Os
 
cadernos
 de 
estudante
  The students’ notebooks
If two people own one thing, add the apostrophe and s to the second person only
A 
filha
 de Hector e Hilda  Hector and Hilda’s daughter
If two people own separate things, add the apostrophe and s for each 
Os
 quartos de Yasmin e Andy  Yasmin’s and Andy’s rooms
Activity
Singular possessive nouns
Example: 
France’s
 soccer team is one of the best. (France)
_________ book is in his backpack. (Felipe)
The __________ window is broken. (House)
The __________  toy is in the room. (Baby)
My __________ name is Felipe.

__data__.text:
(France)
_________ book is in his backpack. (Felipe)
The __________ window is broken. (House)
The __________  toy is in the room. (Baby)
My __________ name is Felipe. (Son)
My __________ name is Andy. (Brother)
Plural possessive nouns
Example: The books of the students.
 
The students’ books.
The tools of the 
doctors.
  ________________________________
The toys of the 
children
.  ________________________________
The parents of the 
girl
.  ________________________________
 The cheeses of the mice  ________________________________
Felipe’s
House’s
Baby’s
Baby 
 babies, baby’s
Son’s
Brother’s
The doctors’ tools
The children’s toys
The girl’s parents
The mice’s cheeses
Activity: write the correct possessive form of the singular nouns
The food of the dog 
 
the dog’s food
The hat of the woman  _________________
The window of the car  _________________
The eyes of the wolf  _________________
 The population of Brazil  _________________
The son of Thais 
 _________________
The woman’s hat
The car’s window
The wolf’s eyes
Brazil’s population
Thais’s
 son
Activity: translate from English to Portuguese
The wolf’s eyes are big.
Os
 
olhos
 do lobo 
são
 
grandes
.
Felipe’s sweater is red.
O 
suéter
 do Felipe 
é
 
vermelho
.
Brazil’s population is 212 million.
A 
população
 do 
Brasil
 
é
 de 212 
milhōes
.
Felipe is 
Thais’s
 son.
Felipe 
é
 
filho
 de Thais.
Activity: translate from Portuguese to English 
Essa é a casa de Ana. 
_________________________________________
Os olhos do Felipe são azuis.
_________________________________________
 
Felipe é filho de Thais.
_________________________________________
Português é a língua oficial do brasil.
_________________________________________
 Quando é o aniversário da sua mãe?
_________________________________________
That is Ana’s house
Felipe’s eyes are blue
Felipe is 
Thais’s
 son
Portuguese is Brazil’s official language
When is your mother’s birthday?
Answering questions using possessive nouns
What is your son’s name?
____________________________________
When is Felipe’s birthday?
____________________________________
What is 
Thais’s
 favorite food?
____________________________________
What is Beverly’s last name?
____________________________________
My son’s name is Felipe
The Felipe’s birthday is July 15.
Thais’s
 favorite food is pizza.
Beverly’s last name is Reyes.
Any questions on possessive pronouns?
Pronouns
Pronouns
Pronouns: takes the place of a noun
Example story:
Beverly is 21 years old. Beverly is a student at Tufts University. Beverly is studying Community Health. Beverly’s house is in Connecticut and Beverly lives with Beverly’s parents.
Example story using pronouns:
Beverly is 21 years old. 
She
 is a student at Tufts University. 
She
 is studying Community Health. 
Her
 house is in Connecticut and 
she
 lives with 
her
 parents.
Personal pronouns
Personal pronouns: refer to a person
Usually replace a name
Examples:
I
 
go to school
She
 works at the bakery
They
 are in class
We
 meet on Thursday nights
He
 is my son
Pronouns that refer to objects
“It” refers to an object
Examples
I love food 
 
I love 
it
The house is big 
 
It
 is big
They cut the cake 
 
They cut 
it
Personal pronouns: subjective pronouns

Lesson 10
Focus: Household chores, good vs. well

Homework review:
1. Three sentences with their, there, they’re.
2. A sentence with it's and a sentence with its.
3. A sentence with your and a sentence with you're.
4. Write three sentences; one talking about something you have (use my/mine), 
one about something your husband has (use his), and one about something your 
family has (using our or ours)
5. A sentence talking about how many times you work a day and a sentence about 
how many times you work a week.

Review! Fill in the possessive adjective or pronoun 
• I have a pencil It is _my_ pencil.
• She has a box. It is _her_ box. 
• He has a phone. It is __his__ phone. 
• We just bought a car. The car is _ours__ now. 
• You have a water bottle. It is __your__ water bottle.
• They have a picture frame. It is __their__ picture frame
• The picture doesn’t fit in the frame.__Its__ frame is too small. 
• I think that is their dog. That dog is probably _theirs_.

Review! Its vs. it’s 
• __It’s_ my turn to drive.
• That is my dog and that is _its__ food over there.
• No, _it’s__ not time to go to sleep yet. 

Review! Your vs. you’re
• Is this __your__ jacket?
• _You’re_ on your way, right?
• I found _your_ car keys!

Review! Their, there, they’re
• I am on my way _there__!
• _They’re_ driving here now. 
• That is not _their_ cat. 

Household chores/ activities
Where is she?  The kitchen
What is she doing? Washing dishes

Where is she? The kitchen
What is she doing? Cooking/baking

Where is he? The dining room
What is he doing? Setting the table
What is he holding? Red plates

What is she doing? Sweeping the floor
What is she using? A broom and dust pan

Where is he? The laundry room
What is he doing? Laundry (washing clothes)

What is she doing? Ironing
What is she using? An iron, ironing board, spray bottle, hangers

Where is she? The living room
What is she doing? Vaccuming

What is she doing? Cleaning the window
What is she using? Paper towels, spray bottle (windex), duster

Where is she? Bedroom
What is she doing? Making the bed

What is he doing? Mopping
What is using? Mop, bucket, soap, sponge

What is he doing? Taking out the trash

Reading and worksheet 
• https://www.elcivics.com/worksheets/read-aloud-laundry.pdf
• https://www.elcivics.com/lifeskills/washing-dishes.pdf

More practice- respond in full sentences!
• How often do you take the trash out in a week?
• How many times do you cook in a day?
• How many days a week do you make your bed in the morning?
• What is your favorite household chore?
• What is your least favorite household chore?

“good” vs. “well”
• Good= adjective (modifies noun)
• Something that can be or seem good
• Examples (identify the noun in each):
• I have a very good dog.
• I am having a good day. 
• I had a good weekend.
• Well= adverb (modifies verb)
• An action can be done well; ***well can be an adjective when talking about health
• Examples (identify the verb in each):
• My dog is behaving very well. 
• Today is going well. 
• You cook very well.
• I am not feeling very well.

Identify whether good/well is modifying a verb or 
noun then choose which sentence is correct!
• I had a good weekend. 
• I had a well weekend. 

• My exam went well. 
• My exam went good. 

• This lasagna is good!
• This lasagna is well!

• Did you do good on your exam?
• Did you do well on your exam?

Lesson 17
Focus: geographical vocabulary and vocab from last week!

Talk about our days!
• How are you feeling?
• How was your day?
• What did you do?
• What did you eat?
• How was yesterday?
• What are you doing for the rest of the week?

Homework review!
• Review comparative adjective worksheet

• 3 sentences:
• comparing family members
• comparing animals
• comparing anything you want!

Superlative and comparative adjective practice!
• That is the __silliest__ (silly) child I have ever met. 
• You are __smarter____ (smart) than they are.
• That is my ____most polite___ (polite) friend.
• You are ___taller___ (tall) than you were as a kid.
• She is the __kindest_____ (kind) person.
• My cat is ____lazier____ (lazy) than my dog.
• We are _____busier___ (busy) today than we were yesterday.
• I could not be ___happier_____ (happy) than I am right now. 
• Last night I had the ___most enjoyable_______ (enjoyable) dinner.

• Is she still ____smarter____ (smart) than you?
• That is the ____most colorful_____ (colorful) painting I have ever seen!
• Who is the ___funniest___ (funny) person in your family?
• That is the _brightest____ (bright) star I have ever seen. 
• I have never been ___angrier___ (angry) than I was yesterday.
• She is the ____most cheerful____ (cheerful) person.
• Most women are ___weaker__ (weak) than men.
• That is the ___noisiest____ (noisy) group of people.
• Where is the ___closest___ (close) coffee shop?
• You are ___more curious_____ (curious) than I am.
• That is the ____best__ (good) ice cream I have ever had!

The guy on the right is taller than the small guy.

The blue flowers are more beautiful than the pink ones.

I like warmer weather better than stormy weather.

The girl on the left has shorter hair than the girl on the right.

Red apples are the most delicious.

• Peaceful: Marcus is more peaceful than Bruna.
• Smart: Marcus is smarter than Liz.
• Crazy: They are crazier than me. 
• Noisy: They are the noisiest people.
• Bad: The bad guys are worse than the good guys.

Words from last week!
• Sloppy: messy/ careless
• If you always make a mess and don’t clean it up you are very sloppy. 

• Sane: right in the head (not crazy)

• Filthy: Very dirty!
• If you play in dirt, you will be filthy after.

• Cowardly: lacking courage 
This Photo by Unknown Author is licensed under CC BY-SA
(like lion in wizard of oz!)

• Dull: lacking interesting/ excitement or less sharp
• If it is lacking color is is very dull
• If something that was once sharp isn’t anymore, it has become dull

• Fierce: having an intense aggressiveness
• If you are fierce you are feared (fierce competitor= good competitor)

• Courageous: brave; doesn’t give up because of danger or pain

Match the antonyms!!
• Sloppy
• Sane
• Filthy
• Cowardly
• Dull
• Fierce
• Courageous 
• Clean
• Tame/ gentle
• cowardly
• Neat
• Brave
• Bright
• Crazy

Earth, globe; planet

continents

countries

states

City (urban area)
Countryside (rural area)

air
water
land

Types of water!
Salt à ocean
Fresh à lake

(also fresh but smaller than lake)
(narrower bodies of water)
pond
river

beach

wave

waterfall

Piece of land with no land attached to it (fully surrounded by water)
island

mountain

hill

desert

Woods/ forest

The edge of land by water à coast
